item.title: Creating an instance
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded:
Starting an instance is really straightforward if you have acquired a license from Adobe. 1. Create a new folder for your instance. 2. Place the aem-quickstart jar file within that file, along with the license.properties file. (2.b If you don't have a license file you will be prompted for a license code and this file will be generated automatically) 3. Rename the file to choose the instance type. The naming pattern is: cq-<instance-type>-p<port-number>.jar. This means that cq-author-p4502.jar would create an author instance on port 4502, and cq-publish-p4503.jar would create a publish instance on port 4503. 4. Double click the .jar file and the following should appear: By default the author instance will be installed on port 4502. This will run the installer and create a folder for your instance called crx-quickstart. From now on you can start your instance by going to crx-quickstart/bin and open the start batch file.

No Sample Content

Included in the instance above is the sample data for the Geometrix website. To create an instance without sample content do the following:
  1. Create a new folder for you instance
  2. Place the aem-quickstart jar file within that file, along with the license.properties file.
  3. Open command prompt and navigate to your new folder.
  4. Run the following command (first change the red text to the name of your .jar file):
java -jar aem-quickstart.jar -r nosamplecontent
item.excerpt:encoded: This is the excerpt for your very first post.

item.title: Custom Logger
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded:
When developing it is important to be able to analyse what exactly is happening within the code. The most straightforward way is to create your own log file to which you can print your debug statements. This is quite simple. Open 
http://localhost:4502/system/console/slinglog
Press "Add new Logger" and edit the name of your log file. Example:
logs\debugger.log
and configure the Logger field. Enter the name of the package you intend to debug. In my case: 
com.valtech.aemstartup.core
Log level should be what ever you want, but just keep in mind to use the correct command in the code. Press save. From now on I always enter the following line into my class declerations: [code langugage="java"] protected Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(this.getClass()); [/code] and simply [code language="java"] log.info("MY DEBUG TEXT"); [/code] to write to this new file. The file will be stored in the log folder of the instance: 
\myInstance\crx-quickstart\logs
item.excerpt:encoded: This is the excerpt for a placeholder post.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded: After finishing my degree in Software Engineering I got a job with Valtech as an AEM developer. Up until that point I had never heard of AEM or Adobe's brilliant Marketing Suite but I was eager to learn so I dove in, head first. Unlike other established technologies the documentation for this field is still quite scarce, and I have come to appreciate all the niche blogs that help a new developer like me getting over the first obstacles. My appreciation was so great indeed that I decided to document my own progress publicly, hoping it could eventually help someone that finds him/herself in the same position. If this blog brings even a single developer an "aha!"-moment it has fulfilled its purpose.

item.title: Creating an Archetype
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded: I have followed several tutorials on how to create an archetype. Some did leave me without an apps folder which made it unintuitive to overwrite some libs elements. Here is the method I follow every time I create an archetype to achieve the structure I want. 1. Create a folder in your system. 2. Open command prompt and navigate to that folder. 3. Run the following command: mvn archetype:generate -DarchetypeGroupId=com.adobe.granite.archetypes -DarchetypeArtifactId=aem-project-archetype -DarchetypeVersion=10 -DarchetypeRepository=https://repo.adobe.com/nexus/content/groups/public/ 4. Answer all the questions you are prompted with. This link might help with naming conventions. 5. Open your IDE and import your new Maven Project.

item.title: Editing the DAM
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded:
I want to establish a project where I can edit the author environment, in this case the DAM. In this project I will locate the buttons (f.x "Create Folder") in the CRXDE and integrate it into a Maven Project where I can make my changes. The picture shows the current buttons available in the DAM, "search", "Timeline", "References" etc. I want to edit the button "Create Folder". The following post is my train of thoughts while solving this task. I am using IntelliJ and a Maven Archetype I created following these instructions. So I have the following project structure:

Find "Create Folder" button in CRXDE Lite

When the button is pressed a modal window pops out and offers some dialog, and then a Cancel and Create button. Let's find it in the CRXDE Lite. My strategy is using the query tool and looking for a node that contains the text "Create Folder". By looking into the results you see that there are two folders that come into play: 
/libs/dam/gui/content/commons/something and /libs/dam/gui/content/assets/something...
This leads me to the following two nodes: 
/libs/dam/gui/content/commons/sidepanels/search/items/createfolder
/libs/dam/gui/content/assets/jcr:content/body/assetscontent/header/items/default/items/createfolder
The GUI we are editing is located under /libs/dam/gui and for this project I am going to integrate it all into my workspace. So I create  a package in the package manager. Then I choose Edit and Filters and add a filter: /libs/dam/gui.

Merging the package to my project

Then I build and download the package, and unzip it on my machine. The unzipped folder will have an archetype structure, starting with two folder jcr_root and META-INF. Now I open my project folder in the explorer and move the folder called "dam" from the package, into the apps folder of my project: 
\ui.apps\src\main\content\jcr_root\apps
This will create the following structure: Now we have to make sure that this dam folder will be used instead of the one in libs. Open a file called filter.xml located here: 
\ui.apps\src\main\content\META-INF\vault
and make sure that it has the following line: 
<filter root="/apps/dam" />
Now you can start editing the GUI from your own project. Try for example to open this .content.xml file: 
\ui.apps\src\main\content\jcr_root\apps\dam\gui\content\assets\_jcr_content\body\assetscontent\header\.content.xml
and change the create folder tag. Try changing text and title to "Create Folder - FIX". Run a maven install. Voila:

Results

Now you have a project in your own IDE where you can edit and the functionality of the author environment. The libs folder should never be tempered with so this is the method you should use to change or extend any out-of-the-box components.

item.title: From CRXDE to IDE
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded:
I've now stumbled onto scenarios where I want to export code from the CRXDE to my IDE. Sometimes I need it to make modifications, but other times I just want to examine the code behind some components or configurations. Also,  a lot of development tutorials on AEM are shown through the CRXDE. But in my case at least, I need all my code to be in an IDE. So being able to follow these tutorials, and ending up with all the source code that can be deployed on a new instance is valuable to me. This can be done by creating a package, building it and downloading and placing within the folder structure on your file system, like explained in another post. But that is a pretty large scale procedure, when all you want are several lines of code maybe. So I decided to look into the VLT tool which maps your instance with your code. After some initial setup work merging the JCR with your code becomes very fast and convenient.

Journey

  • Install VLT Tools
  • Export code from CRXDE

Installing VLT Tools

Navigate to the following folder: 
\YourInstanceFolder\crx-quickstart\opt\filevault
Copy the compressed folder filevault.zip and paste it to some other folder on your file system. I chose a folder that I use to store various tools: 
 C:/tools
Extract the content of the zip to that location. Then you need to edit your Environment Variables to recognise VLT as a command. Add the path of the bin folder within the filevault folder to the PATH variable: Now you can open the command prompt and type 
vlt --help
to make sure the installation was successful.

Exporting from CRXDE to your IDE

After setting up the VLT

References

http://www.aemcq5tutorials.com/tutorials/configure-filevault-vlt-tool-in-cq/ https://docs.adobe.com/docs/en/crx/2-3/how_to/how_to_use_the_vlttool.html

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Steps to Configure FileVault Tool (VLT) in CQ

item.title: Blogging with AEM
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded:
I want to explore the blogging capabilities of CQ5. I want users to be able to log in and write entries, and I want a clear overview over contributions and some archive. Turns out, this is really easy to implement using the Social Journal library which ships with CQ. An example of this journal, or blog feature can be found under the Geometrixx Outdoors site. I want to extract the elements used to create this journal, and use it for my own purposes.

Journey

  1. Extract necessary components and import to my project.
  2. Modify the .content.xml files.
  3. Create the site structure for the journal.
 

Extracting components and templates

I extract the components and templates found under the geometrixx site. More detailed instructions on that step can be found here. The package has the following filters: /apps/geometrixx-outdoors/templates/page_journal /apps/geometrixx-outdoors/templates/page_new_journal_ugc /apps/geometrixx-outdoors/templates/page_edit_journal_ugc /apps/geometrixx-outdoors/components/page_editjournal /apps/geometrixx-outdoors/components/page_journal /apps/geometrixx-outdoors/components/page_newjournal Build and download the package and import into the template and component folder of my project, which is structured like explained here.

Modifying the .content.xml files

First the templates have to be updated, so the resourceType parameters points to the correct component. So for all templates: [code language="xml"] sling:resourceType="myProject/components/page_journal" [/code] where: Template page_journal has resource type "page_journal", Template page_new_joiurnal_ugc has resource type "page_newjournal" and Template page_edit_journal_ugc has resource type "page_editjournal". Furthermore, the allowedPaths parameters should be updated for all templates, to suit my project. For my purposes, I just allow all paths so: [code language="xml"] allowedPaths="[(/.*)?]"[/code] As for the components, the page_editjournal and page_newjournal components both point to the page_journal component as its super type. So that path has to be updated accordingly in both .content.xml files: [code language="xml"]sling:resourceSuperType="myProject/components/page_journal"[/code] We'll come back to the .content.xml files but before making further changes, we have to decide the structure of our pages.

Page Structure

This is the structure you have to set up for the journal. Make sure that your allowedPaths parameter gives you access to the templates where you need them: For clarity, I have named the pages after the templates I used. Note down the path to the sites. In my case: /content/page_journal etc. Now add the following property to all templates, under the jcr:root: [code language="xml"]editForm="/content/journal/editpost/" [/code] This path points to the location of my edit page. In the edit page also update two parameters in the "start" node: [code language="xml"] action="/content/journal" redirect="/content/journal" [/code] By now, if you open your journal page, it should look like this: Edit the "New Post" link and make sure it points to your edit page. Press that link and open the edit page. Press edit, next to start of Form, and in the Advanced tab, make sure the content path points to your journal site. In my case it is /content/journal. If you have a specific thank you page, this is where you configure it.

Result

Now the journal should be functioning. Archives are automatically created as well as overview over entries by authors. Each entry will be created as a subpage and organized based on date of creation. The search engine is also automatically configured and works out of the box. The main functions are ready and now you can apply your styles or extensions to suit your particular use case.

References:

Using Social Journal Components
item.excerpt:encoded: I want to explore the blogging capabilities of CQ5. I want users to be able to log in and write entries, and I want a clear overview over contributions and some archive. Turns out, this is really easy to implement using the Social Journal library which ships with CQ.

item.title: From WordPress to CQ
item.dc:creator: karithrastarson
item.content:encoded:
A client I am working for has a blog that has to be moved from WordPress to CQ 5. The blog contains 500 blog entries by different authors. I want to preserve as much as possible as I migrate the content to a social blog on the CQ platform.   There is a nifty tool that ships with CQ called feed importer. I am going to make use of this tool and migrate all the blogs from my WordPress feed.

Journey

  1. Modify my RSS feed on the WordPress site.
  2. Create a blank root page for the blogs.
  3. Use the feed importer

RSS Feed

Your RSS feed on WordPress is by default set to 10; meaning that a tool like the feed importer would only have access to the last 10 entries. Navigate to the WP-Admin console -> Settings -> Reading Settings. Find the "Syndication feeds show the most recent" and change that value to however many entries you need to migrate.

Site Structure and the feed importer

I use the "Blank Page" template for the root page for the migrated content. Then I navigate to http://localhost:4502/miscadmin and under "Importers" I find the feed importer: http://localhost:4502/etc/importers/polling.html Press "Add" and fill in the fields. I will migrate the entries from this particular WordPress site for this example: Type is RSS, the URL is the URL to the WordPress site plus "/feed/rss/" in the end. You can try opening this URL to see the format. In the third field you find the blank page you created earlier. Press OK and then Refresh. Now if you open your websites explorer you see that your blank root page has the following structure:

Result

Now you have successfully migrated all of your entries from the WordPress site to your CQ instance. You further style the entries by choosing another template for your root page. To continue blogging using CQ see this entry. Try using a social journal template for the root and see the outcome.
